children.subject: I can't give you any meaningful help, but if you can't find enough information on eecs 101, try searching the berkeley subreddit (reddit.com/r/berkeley). I'm fairly certain I've seen this discussed there a handful of times (though some of the people there aren't always the nicest, so keep in mind how that might influence what you are seeing). One thing I seem to remember seeing is some website which gives you problems to practice on, though I can't speak to how helpful it might be.

history.content: Cracking the Coding Interview is a great start. It has a lot of problems and also has conceptual review. Don't feel incompetent, the ind of problems you see in coding challenges and interviews are often different from the type of challenges we are presented in class. Everyone is in the same boat, and the best thing you can do is practice. Leetcode is great for this as an endless source of practice problems. I also really liked firecode.io, it gives you problems to do in an organized manner while Leetcode is more of a vast database of problems. 61B is enough for many of the problems you'll see, but 170 helps out as well with the more complicated problem types (Dynamic Programming, advanced graph search, etc.) Make sure you have the basics of 61B down (http://bigocheatsheet.com) is a great source for this, know your runtimes, know why the runtimes are why they are, know the sort algorithms/tradeoffs (Ex. Why might it be better to use merge sort over quick sort?, When can quick sort not be the best choice?, etc.). Hope that helps!

children.subject: I'm curious if you had any suggestions for personal projects as well. My resume mostly has school projects so I'd like to have something different to help boost it.

Yes! If you have any personal projects put that on there. This would make you stand out from the other students that have also done the same projects. From the standpoint of a recruiter, they usually are not impressed with school projects that they see on multiple resumes. But it doesn't hurt. If you still need more things to put on your resume: 

  • Join a CS project based club on campus and put that project on your resume 
  • Start working on another personal project and you can state that it is a project that is in progress (just make sure you have stuff to say about it)
  • Do research with faculty  
  • If your GPA is good, put your GPA on there

Hi, great question! First off, don't feel discouraged. Many students, including myself, have phases of struggling before landing their first offer. I can give you countless entertaining/embarrassing stories of my recruiting experiences - starting off with accidently saying "f%$k" in a middle of yelp phone interview. But after thousands of mess ups, I ended up with offers from some well known companies and startups doing cool things like self driving cars.  

In regards to tangible advice, I would begin with spending about a week brushing up on all the data structures that you learned in CS61B (linked lists, trees, stacks, etc.). Look through some of the labs and discussions and know how to do some of problems. Don't get too caught up on this, the main purpose is to brush up. Once you have done this, begin doing problem on leetcode, hackerrank, and 'Cracking The Coding Interview'. After every problem you complete, always think about the runtime and space complexity. In addition to practicing online, also practice writing out your answers to prepare for whiteboarding interviews. Even better, get a group of friends (or just a friend) to do mock whiteboard interviews. It's all about practice and repetition. 

Lastly, there is a student organization on campus, called Codeology, that dedicates their time to helping students like you prepare for coding and behavioral interviews! More information about them can be found on Facebook.

history.content:
Not sure if this is the right place to be asking this, but what sort of tips do any of you have for internship recruiting? I've received a few coding challenges and found them to be extremely difficult and it's making me realize how incompetent I really am lol

Is reading through Cracking the Coding Interview recommended? Or are there other resources? For reference I've only taken up to 61B and ended up doing average in the class.
history.subject: Tips for Internship Recruiting?
